citation.article-title: Phylogenetic analysis of 18 thermophilic Methanobacterium isolates supports the proposals to create a new genus, Methanothermobacter gen. nov., and to reclassify several isolates in three species, Methanothermobacter thermautotrophicus comb. nov., Methanothermobacter wolfeii comb. nov., and Methanothermobacter marburgensis sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methanothermobacter marburgensis sp. nov.
Methanothermobacter marburgensis (mar.bur.gen'sis. German n. Marburg name of a city in Germany; M.L. masc. suffix -ensis pertaining to/originating from a locality; M.L. n. marburgensis from Marburg)
Cells are slender, cylindrical rods that are 0.30-0.4 μm wide and 3.0-3.5 μm long and frequently occur in pairs or chains up to 20 μm long.
Colonies on agar plates are 1-4 mm in diameter, white or slightly yellowish, and convex.
Growth is rapid in mineral medium with CO2 as the sole carbon source, NH$ as the sole nitrogen source, sulfide as the sole sulfur source and H2/CO2 as the sole energy source.
Growth on formate is not possible.
Not stimulated by organic additions, although acetate may be assimilated.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 48 mol% as determined by thermal denaturation.
Strains may harbour one plasmid, and the type strain is infected by lytic phages.
Habitat: mesophilic sewage sludge and hot springs.
The type strain is strain MarburgT (=DSM 2133T), which was isolated from mesophilic sewage sludge.
